awd_titl_txt: Building for Future Discoveries: Instrumentation, Algorithms, and Training for Physics with the ATLAS Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Chicago particle physics group will develop, commission, and operate new instrumentation for the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider that will enable novel searches for new physics as well as key measurements of Standard Model processes.  By combining their expertise in instrumentation, physics analysis, and data-intensive computation with novel ideas in machine learning and electronics design, they will extend sensitivities to groundbreaking discoveries. 

The group will: (a) Conduct searches for new physics and detailed measurements of the Standard Model (SM) involving electroweak (EW) processes and hadronic final states; (b) Expand their roles in commissioning and operating the Tile calorimeter and global Feature Extractor (gFEX) calorimeter trigger system; (c) Undertake three detector upgrades for the High Luminosity LHC Run 4: Tile Calorimeter Main Board electronics, the calorimeter Global Event Processor (GEP), and the Hardware Track Trigger (HTT) systems.

The Chicago group’s physics analysis activities include exploration of the electroweak/Higgs sector; exploration of the dark sector; and exploration of the hard QCD sector. Each has the potential for transformative discoveries and insights in particle physics. The group will expand its roles in several areas as the ATLAS physics program and the HL-LHC upgrade program progress, including calibrating, operating, and upgrading the Tile Calorimeter and commissioning the trigger system for Run 3, as well as upgrading the Global Event Processor (GEP) and Hardware Track Trigger (HTT) trigger systems, and the associated computing paradigms, for the HL-LHC.

The proposed instrumentation efforts enable the group to have a long-lasting impact on research in physics more broadly. The group also aims to have an impact on workforce development, K-12 education, and enhanced public scientific literacy. They will incorporate new programs and activities based on group members' successful experiences and alignment with best practices. These activities comprise a comprehensive approach to training, educating, and increasing scientific literacy as they advance scientific knowledge. At the same time, the group will train graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in a broad range of methods, experimental design, leadership, and communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview

This project focused on advancing the search for new fundamental particles at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), with an emphasis on Supersymmetry (SUSY) and other beyond-the-Standard-Model theories. To achieve this goal, we developed cutting-edge data analysis techniques, high-speed electronics for real-time data selection, and critical upgrades to the ATLAS experiment’s hadronic calorimeter and trigger systems. These advancements enhanced our ability to detect and study complex particle interactions, pushing the boundaries of high-energy physics.

Beyond the research itself, the project included a strong educational component, integrating high-energy physics into undergraduate curricula and engaging K-12 students—particularly those from underrepresented communities—through specially-designed programs at the University of Chicago.

Intellectual Merit

The scientific goals of this project targeted key searches for new physics, focusing on unique experimental signatures involving hadronic final states. Our work included:
  • Searching for pair-produced SUSY stop quarks decaying via an R-parity violating interaction.
  • Investigating gluino pair production, where gluinos cascade into multi-quark final states or decay invisibly, leading to missing transverse energy (MET) signatures.
  • Developing novel trigger algorithms that enable real-time selection of rare physics events, improving ATLAS’s ability to capture potential signs of new particles.
Through these efforts, we contributed to the global search for new physics at the LHC while also refining techniques for analyzing vast amounts of collider data. The insights gained from this work will continue to inform future searches and experimental strategies.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this project extend beyond particle physics research into education, technology development, and public engagement.
  • Advancing Experimental Capabilities: The high-speed electronics and machine learning-based trigger algorithms developed in this project improve the LHC’s ability to capture rare events, benefiting the entire high-energy physics community.
  • Education and Workforce Development: This research was integrated into undergraduate coursework, providing students with hands-on exposure to high-energy physics methods. Several students were mentored through research projects, strengthening the pipeline of future physicists and engineers.
  • Outreach to K-12 Students: We led programs such as the Lane Tech High School UChicago Outreach Program and the Enrico Fermi Summer Interns Program, engaging young students—particularly those from underprivileged backgrounds—in physics experiments and data analysis, fostering early interest in STEM careers.

Conclusion

This project has made significant contributions to both fundamental physics research and STEM education. The methodologies developed—ranging from real-time data processing to novel calorimeter upgrades—will have lasting impacts on future LHC experiments. Equally important, the education and outreach initiatives have inspired the next generation of scientists and broadened participation in high-energy physics. By combining innovation in instrumentation, algorithms, and training, this project has strengthened the foundation for future discoveries in fundamental physics.
